In the Verus DeFi ecosystem, a currency can be created and backed by a liquidity pool consisting of one or more reserve currencies. The value of the Verus DeFi currency is derived from the value of the currencies in its liquidity pool. For example, if a liquidity pool consists of VRSC and ETH, the value of the Verus DeFi currency will fluctuate based on the values of VRSC and ETH.

The liquidity pool acts as an automated market maker, which means that the price of the Verus DeFi currency is determined automatically based on the values of the currencies in the pool. This automated market maker ensures that there is always liquidity available, as anyone can interact with the currency at any time. The liquidity pool can never be empty, as users can always add or remove VRSC and ETH, and arbitrage opportunities arise when the balance tips too much to one side.

Holding a Verus DeFi currency provides a constant-mix strategy, exposing the user to multiple currencies while only holding one. Additionally, users can earn fees from conversion transactions. The Verus DeFi currency can be backed by 100% of the liquidity pool, and multiple currencies can be used in the pool, offering various combinations.

In the Verus ecosystem, a currency with a liquidity pool attached is called a "fractional currency," and the currencies in the pool are referred to as "reserve currencies." The term "fractional currency" is used because the value of the currency is derived from the value of the reserve currencies, making it a fraction of their combined value.
